Award.AwardTitle: The In Vivo Rice RNA Structurome in Abiotic Stress Sensing and Response
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Philip C. Bevilacqua (Penn State University)

CoPIs: David H. Mathews (University of Rochester) and Sarah M. Assmann (Penn State University)

Rice is a staple food for more than 1/3 of the world's population and the second most important crop in terms of global production. Given global population growth, limited resources of fresh water, and global warming, it is very important to develop stress-tolerant varieties of rice. This research has the potential to advance both basic and applied knowledge regarding how RNA structure regulates expression of diverse genes in response to abiotic stresses, information that may useful for crop improvement. In addition to the training of students and postdoctoral associates, this project will provide summer training for underrepresented high school students in math and sciences in collaboration with the SEECoS program (http://science.psu.edu/outreach/special-programs/seecos-summer-experience-in-the-eberly-college-of-science) at Penn State. This project will also contribute to a new training program for ethics at Penn State and to an ethics module on Genetic Manipulation. All project outcomes will be made available to the public. Sequence data will be available at http://rna.urmc.rochester.edu/ and through long term repositories such as the NCBI-SRA, Galaxy, and the Single Nucleotide Resolution Nucleic Acid Structure Mapping (SNRNASM; http://snrnasm.bio.unc.edu/)website. Biological materials generated in this project will be available on request or through the Dale Bumpers National Rice Resource Center.

When plants are subjected to drought, molecular crowding within cells is enhanced and osmolyte and K+ concentrations increase. Likewise, when plants are stressed from temperature, RNAs in cells are thermodynamically affected. Taken together, these observations suggest that drought and temperature regulate RNA folding, and that RNA structure may play a central role in regulating gene expression and stress tolerance in rice. To evaluate the contribution of RNA structural changes to the regulation of gene expression in rice, this project will leverage, advance and apply recently developed in vivo and computational tools to reveal, on a genome-wide basis, how RNA folds in vivo in rice during drought and temperature stress.

POR.DRECONTENT:
WIth extreme changes in climate affecting our planet, crops are under increasing stress including high temperature and salinity from inundation of seawater.  Temperature changes refold RNA, which is an important biomolecule inside of all living organisms. Under this funding, we provided insights into how plants perceive heat and salinity while also developing a new and improved techniques called Structure-seq for probing the structure of tens of thousands of RNA structures in plants.  

(1) New Insights into thermosensing. We applied our method for assessing RNA structure in the crop rice across tens of thousands RNAs during heat stress.  We subjected rice seedlings to acute heat shock, to simulate conditions found in the field, and found significantly elevated RNA reactivity to a the chemical called DMS, indicative of RNA unfolding (Figure 1). Our analyses indicated that heat-induced mRNA changes control how plants respond to stress. We also gained insight into changes in root and shoot tissues in the RNA structurome upon salinity stress in the model plant Arabidopsis, where the different tissues were affected differently (Figure 2). Using Arabidopsis, we also identified a surprising correlation between nucleic acids and proteins, two very different biomolecules (Figure 3).

(2) Technique Development. We improved our genome-wide method in Structure-seq2, which increases sensitivity and removes various confounding biases in the data. We developed a chemical called EDC to complement the reactivity of DMS.  This is important because we now have data on all four bases in the RNA, rather than just two (Figure 4). In addition, we developed a chemical (glyoxal) that probes the base G in its rare charged form, which may confer key attributes to the RNA that could lead to insights into engineering crops with more favorable properties. We also substantially improved computational analysis of RNA structure for the community via the development and publication of StructureFold2, which offers a suite of user-friendly utilities that may help others in the field understand how RNA affects crops (Figure 5). With the Mathews lab, we developed Rsample, a computer program that uses chemical reactivity data to predict the probability and structure of each fold of an RNA sequence that adopts multiple folds (Figure 6).

Broader Impacts: We trained a number of scientists. Two Ph.D. students (Yin Tang, now a postdoc at Yale) and Laura Ritchey (now a tenure-track faculty member at University of Pittsburgh-Johnstown) and three B.S. students (Marissa Gentle (PSU), Cole Schailey (PSU), and Jessica Freeze (UR)) were graduated, and seven postdoctoral fellows (Hong-Li Chou (PSU), Angel Ferrero-Serrano (PSU), David Mitchell (PSU), Alex Spasic (UR), Zhao Su (PSU), David Tack (PSU), Jeffrey Zuber (UR)) were supported. Three current graduate students (Megan Sylvia (PSU), Allison Williams (PSU), and Mohammad Kayedkhordeh (UR), and two undergraduates (Glenn Duncan (PSU) and Brendan Courtsal (UR)) were supported. This cohort of trainees includes 6 women, 2 African-American scientists and 1 Hispanic scientist. Technical advances in the forms of Structure-seq2 and StructureFold2 enable the broader scientific community to probe RNA structural changes in vivo in different domains of life. The ability to probe all four bases in vivo as provided by the chemical tools we developed multiplies these impacts. Additional broader impacts include diversity of trainees in terms of gender, ethnicity, and scientific background, including 5 trainees from chemistry, 5 from biology, and 6 from bioinformatics. Dr. Bevilacqua incorporated principles of plant biology into his new Chemistry contextualized for Biology course (CHEM110B). In public outreach, our rice RNA structurome study was featured on the PBS NOVA website (https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/article/climate-change-plants-high-temperature). In all, we published 14 research papers, 5 reviews, and a book chapter under this support, and we released our data to the public via appropriate websites.
